questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to increased thirst and urination for the last month. The patient has no medical history, and he currently takes no medications. The patient’s mother notes that her father had a similar condition. The patient is at the 40th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg.  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood, serum, plasma 
Sodium   136 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride   83 mEq/L 
 Uric Acid  10 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  46 mEq/L 
Urinalysis shows elevated calcium excretion. Which of the following is most likely affected in this patient?

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
This patient with growth retardation, polyuria, polydipsia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis most likely has Bartter syndrome. Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular defect caused by a mutation in the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. The loss of this cotransporter leads to excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride in the urine, as well as excessive loss of extracellular water. The depletion of extracellular water then leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which prompts the excretion of hydrogen and more potassium, as well as the reabsorption of bicarbonate. Therefore, common laboratory findings in patients with Bartter syndrome include metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia. Despite the loss of sodium through the urine, there is no hyponatremia, due to the concomitant loss of water.

The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is also responsible for calcium reabsorption via an electrochemical gradient created by the reabsorption of sodium, potassium, and chloride. As a result, patients with Bartter syndrome commonly present with hypercalciuria. Also, due to increased reabsorption of urate and general volume depletion, patients may also present with hyperuricemia with or without gout.  


It is also worth noting that loop diuretics act by blocking the same cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Therefore, patients with Bartter syndrome present similarly to those with chronic loop diuretic use.  

Option Analysis

❌ Glomerulus:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The glomerulus is affected in nephritic and nephrotic glomerulopathies, which present with hematuria and proteinuria.  
❌ Proximal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The proximal convoluted tubule is affected in Fanconi syndrome, which causes metabolic acidosis.  
✅ Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The distal convoluted tubule is affected in Gitelman syndrome. Gitelman syndrome presents similarly to thiazide diuretic therapy, meaning that urine calcium excretion would be low, not elevated as in this patient.
❌ Collecting duct:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The collecting duct is affected in Liddle syndrome, which causes increased sodium reabsorption, leading to hypertension with hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with severe headaches and nausea for the last two months. The patient has no past medical history, and she takes no medications. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. Laboratory tests are obtained, and she is diagnosed with a renal tubular defect that causes increased sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct of the nephron. Which of the following laboratory findings would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with severe hypertension who is diagnosed with Liddle syndrome most likely has laboratory findings consistent with hypoaldosteronism, hyporeninism, and hypokalemia. Liddle syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a gain of function mutation that leads to increased activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the collecting duct, thereby increasing sodium reabsorption. Normally, ENaC activity is increased by aldosterone, so patients with Liddle syndrome have a clinically identical presentation to those with hyperaldosteronism (i.e. symptomatic hypertension and hypokalemia). However, in patients with Liddle syndrome, laboratory findings show characteristically low levels of aldosterone and renin.

As more sodium is reabsorbed and potassium is excreted, the patient will develop hypertension and hypokalemia. The kidneys will attempt to compensate for these changes by increasing the activity of the K+/H+ ATPase in the collecting duct, which increases hydrogen ion excretion and subsequently causes metabolic alkalosis. Treatment for Liddle syndrome includes a potassium-sparing diuretic, such as amiloride and triamterene, which will block ENaC.  

 

Option Analysis

❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with primary hyperaldosteronism, also known as Conn syndrome. Patients with Liddle syndrome have characteristically low levels of aldosterone.
❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with a renin-secreting tumor. Patients with Liddle syndrome have characteristically low levels of aldosterone.
✅   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which is characterized by hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance.
❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↑  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with Bartter syndrome or Gitelman syndrome, which affect the loop of Henle or the distal convoluted tubule, respectively.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female comes to the primary care physician due to worsening weight gain. She has gained approximately 20 lbs over the past six weeks. In addition, the patient has been experiencing lower extremity edema and has noticed her urine appears more cloudy than usual. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is notable for bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. A urinalysis is notable for 4+ protein and oval fat bodies but no hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the following is visualized on light microscopy:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  
Which of the following is most suggestive of this patient’s underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: IgG4 antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor
IgG autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase

questions.solution:
This patient has worsening weight gain, edema, and a urinalysis revealing proteinuria and oval fat bodies. In addition, light microscopy demonstrates diffuse capillary and glomerular basement membrane thickening. Taking into account these findings, this patient likely has membranous nephropathy, which is associated with the presence of IgG4 antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors.   

Membranous nephropathy, also termed membranous glomerulonephritis, is among the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Primary disease is thought to be due to antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors, with titers correlating with disease severity. Secondary disease is associated with drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, penicillamine) and infections (e.g., HBV, HCV, syphilis). Other associations for secondary disease include systemic lupus erythematosus and solid tumors. Pathogenesis involves subepithelial immune complex deposition, which activates the complement system, resulting in damage to podocytes and mesangial cells.  

Light microscopy will demonstrate diffuse capillary and basement membrane thickening, immunofluorescence will demonstrate a granular appearance due to immune complex deposition, and electron microscopy will demonstrate a spike and dome appearance due to subepithelial deposits. Treatment involves a course of corticosteroids, although patients generally have a poor response to treatment.  



Option Analysis

✅ IgG4 antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased serum levels of C3:
Incorrect: Decreased serum levels of C3 are observed in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. Both conditions are nephritic syndromes. In contrast, this patient's presentation is more consistent with nephrotic syndrome. 
❌ Mutation in type IV collagen:
Incorrect: Alport syndrome is due to a mutation in type IV collagen. This mutation leads to thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane and results in nephritic syndrome. This disease usually presents with associated hearing loss and vision disturbance.
❌ IgG autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase:
Incorrect: Type II membrano-proliferative glomerulonephritis is a nephritic syndrome associated with C3 nephritic factor. Periodic acid-schiff (PAS) and hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stains will demonstrate a “tram-track” appearance. In contrast, this patient’s biopsy reveals diffuse capillary and glomerular basement membrane thickening, which is more consistent with the presentation of membranous nephropathy.
❌ Positive glomerular immunostaining for IgA:
Incorrect: IgA nephropathy is a nephritic syndrome characterized by hematuria. It occurs after or concurrently with respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infections. Renal biopsy will demonstrate IgA immune complex deposition in the mesangium.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation following a motor vehicle accident. Trauma chest/abdomen/pelvis CT-imaging demonstrates multiple bilateral fractures, a right humeral shaft fracture, as well as splenic and liver lacerations with ongoing internal hemorrhage. The patient is resuscitated with type O negative blood and is taken to the operating room for repair of the aforementioned injuries. His condition remains stable postoperatively. Following surgery, his temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. On his second day of hospitalization, his urine output decreases. Urine microscopy demonstrates granular casts and a calculated fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) of 3%. On the patient’s eighth day of hospitalization, a significant increase in urine output is noted. Serum creatinine charting is shown:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 On admission Day 2 Day 8 
Creatinine  1.1 mg/dL  3.5 mg/dL  2.3 mg/dL 

In the coming days, this patient is at highest risk of developing which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
This patient developed acute renal failure following hemorrhagic shock from a motor vehicle accident. The urinalysis findings of granular casts and a FENa>2% on the second postoperative day are consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN), likely secondary to prolonged ischemia.   

The clinical manifestations of ATN are divided into three phases. The initiation phase is defined by tubular injury secondary to an insult. In 24-36 hours, the initiation phase is followed by the maintenance phase, which is characterized by oliguria and volume overload. Tubular dysfunction interferes with reabsorption of sodium, causing increased urinary sodium (>40 mEq/L) and increased FENa(>2%).   

With renal regenerative capacity and adequate management, the patient then enters the recovery phase in one to three weeks. Since glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is increased to overcome volume overload, a transient polyuria can be observed during this phase, which results in losses of up to 3 L/day and associated electrolyte wasting. If not appropriately managed, life threatening electrolyte disturbances resulting in cardiac arrhythmias may occur.


Option Analysis

✅ Hypokalemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hyperphosphatemia:
Incorrect: Hyperphosphatemia is usually observed in the maintenance phase of ATN. This patient’s frank diuresis on day eight and falling creatinine levels are indicative of the recovery phase. 
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: This patient’s spontaneous diuresis and falling creatinine levels indicate the recovery phase of ATN. Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is observed due to wasting in the urine. 
❌ Metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: Metabolic acidosis is observed in the maintenance (oliguric) phase of ATN secondary to failure of excretion of acid anions (particularly phosphates) from damaged tubules. It is not seen in the recovery (polyuric) phase. 
❌ Gross hematuria and proteinuria:
Incorrect: Gross hematuria and proteinuria are observed in renal papillary necrosis or nephritic syndrome (due to glomerular inflammation). Because the necrosis in ATN is largely tubular, these symptoms would be unexpected. Moreover, these conditions do not exhibit granular casts on urine sediment microscopy or polyuria during recovery.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressive fatigue, weight loss, and ankle swelling for the past two months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema around the ankles. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are non-contributory. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine level of 3.1 mg/dL, albumin of 2.2 g/dL, and total cholesterol concentration of 290 mg/dL. Urinalysis results show 3+ proteinuria without hematuria or red cell casts. Renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with pitting edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and biopsy findings revealing Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions. She most likely has diabetic glomerulonephropathy.

Diabetic glomerulonephropathy is the most common cause of end-stage renal disease in the United States. The condition presents with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, including massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. Of note, the hyperlipidemic state is thought to be a method of compensating for the reduction in plasma oncotic pressure due to protein loss via urine.  

The condition arises since hyperglycemia secondary to diabetes mellitus causes nonenzymatic glycation, which leads to mesangial expansion, basement membrane thickening, and podocyte damage. The increased permeability causes glomerular hyperfiltration, which eventually progresses to glomerular hypertrophy and scarring (glomerulosclerosis).  

Biopsy will reveal eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions), which arise due to mesangial matrix expansion. These lesions are Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain positive.    

Option Analysis

❌ Light chain nephropathy:
Incorrect: Light chain nephropathy, which can be seen in patients with multiple myeloma, is a cause of nephrotic syndrome. It occurs when light chains precipitate with uromodulin (formerly termed Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein) and obstruct the renal tubular lumen. On light microscopy, these casts can be seen as amorphous material within the renal tubular lumen. However, light chain nephropathy would not manifest with the Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions seen on this patient’s biopsy. 
❌ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:
Incorrect: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in patients of Hispanic and African-American descent. It can be a primary condition or arise secondary to HIV, sickle cell disease, obesity, or interferon treatment. Biopsy results under light microscopy will show segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis. In other words, only part of the glomerulus is affected. However, the condition would not lead to the formation of Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, which are seen on this patient’s biopsy. 
❌ Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is a condition that often presents concurrently with both nephrotic and nephritic syndrome. It is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The condition can lead to nephrotic range proteinuria (i.e. >3.5 g/day) and clinical features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria, RBC casts in the urine). A biopsy under light microscopy will show wire looping of capillaries. In contrast, this patient has neither hematuria nor wire looping.
✅ Diabetic glomerulonephropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amyloidosis:
Incorrect: Amyloidosis is a cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is associated with systemic amyloidosis and chronic conditions that lead to amyloid deposition (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis). Kidney biopsy will reveal amyloid deposits, which present with an apple-green birefringence under polarized light following Congo red staining.
❌ Membranous nephropathy:
Incorrect: Membranous nephropathy is a cause of nephrotic syndrome. Primary disease can be due to antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors. Secondary disease can be due to drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, penicillamine), infections (e.g., HBV, HCV, syphilis), systemic lupus erythematosus, and solid tumors. Biopsy results under light microscopy will show diffuse capillary and glomerular basement membrane thickening. However, the condition would not manifest with the Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions seen on this patient’s biopsy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with 3 days of difficulty urinating, right flank pain, malaise, and nausea. Medical history includes chronic migraines for the last 10 years, for which she has been taking ibuprofen multiple times daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg. Laboratory testing is obtained and the results are shown below.



Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has urinary symptoms, history of analgesic overuse, hypokalemia, urine pH above 5.5, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. She most likely has a distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and symptoms due to a calcium phosphate kidney stone. 



Distal RTA is caused by a genetic or acquired defect of α-intercalated cells in the distal tubule and collecting duct, which prevents them from secreting hydrogen. This defect leads to a buildup of hydrogen in the blood, resulting in acidemia and metabolic acidosis. To maintain electroneutrality, there is increased excretion of potassium in the renal tubules and hypokalemia. Patients with distal RTA have alkaline urine pH, usually above 5.5, and increased calcium excretion without increased calcium absorption. This mismatch leads to increased bone turnover and predisposition to developing calcium phosphate kidney stones.  





Genetic causes of distal RTA include mutations in the H+ ATPase or H+/K+ ATPase pump of α-intercalated cells. Acquired distal RTA may be due to adverse medication reactions (e.g., amphotericin B, analgesics), congenital urinary tract anomalies, or autoimmune diseases (e.g. SLE), all which can damage the distal and collecting tubules and decrease hydrogen secretion.   

Option Analysis

❌ Reduced aldosterone release :
Incorrect: Reduced aldosterone release would cause a hyperkalemic (type 4) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). The condition presents with a urine pH < 5.5 and hyperkalemia. In contrast, this patient has a urine pH > 5.5 and hypokalemia, which is more consistent with a type 1 RTA.  
❌ Respiratory muscle fatigue:
Incorrect: Respiratory muscle fatigue can develop over time due to hyperventilation. It would result in respiratory acidosis, which presents with an elevated pCO2. In contrast, this patient has findings more consistent with a metabolic acidosis. 
✅ Decreased hydrogen secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased cystine excretion :
Incorrect: Increased excretion of cystine into the urine can cause cystine stone formation. This patient has laboratory findings consistent with a type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which increases urine calcium and leads to calcium phosphate stone formation. 
❌ Increased bicarbonate excretion:
Incorrect: Increased excretion of bicarbonate would cause a type 2 renal tubular acidosis (RTA). This patient has a high urine pH and hypokalemia, which is more consistent with type 1 RTA.
